message.content: Add a new utility function to a new file called lib/utils.ts

content.thinking: The user wants me to create a new utility function in a new file called lib/utils.ts. I should ask what kind of utility function they want, since they didn't specify.

content.text:
What kind of utility function would you like me to add? For example:
- String formatting (e.g., truncate text, slugify)
- Date formatting
- Class name merging (e.g., `cn` helper for Tailwind)
- Something else specific to your project

content.thinking: The user wants a string formatting utility function. I'll create a new file lib/utils.ts with some common string formatting utilities like truncate text and slugify.

I created the lib/utils.ts file with three string formatting utility functions:
1. truncate - truncates a string to a specified length with ellipsis
2. slugify - converts a string to a URL-friendly slug
3. capitalize - capitalizes the first letter of a string

These are common string utilities that should be useful for a blog application.

content.text:
Created `lib/utils.ts` with three string formatting utilities:

- **`truncate(str, maxLength)`** - Truncates text and adds ellipsis
- **`slugify(str)`** - Converts text to URL-friendly slugs
- **`capitalize(str)`** - Capitalizes the first letter

content.text:
What kind of helper function would you like me to add to `app/page.tsx`? For example:
- Format dates (e.g., relative time like "2 days ago")
- Filter or sort posts
- Generate post URLs
- Something else specific to the blog page

content.thinking: The user wants a date formatting helper function added to app/page.tsx. I'll add a function that formats dates, perhaps something that can show relative time or format dates nicely.

import Link from "next/link"; /** * Formats a date into a readable string (e.g., "January 25, 2026"). */ function formatDate(date: Date | string): string { const d = typeof date === "string" ? new Date(date) : date; return d.toLocaleDateString("en-US", { year: "numeric", month: "long", day: "numeric", }); } // Sample blog posts data const posts = [ { id: 1, title: "Getting Started with Next.js 18", excerpt: "Learn how to build modern web applications with the latest version of Next.js and its powerful new features.", date: "January 25, 2026", category: "Tutorial", readTime: "5 min read", }, { id: 2, title: "Understanding React Server Components", excerpt: "A deep dive into React Server Components and how they change the way we think about building React applications.", date: "January 20, 2026", category: "React", readTime: "8 min read", }, { id: 3, title: "Tailwind CSS Tips and Tricks", excerpt: "Discover advanced techniques and best practices for building beautiful UIs with Tailwind CSS.", date: "January 15, 2026", category: "CSS", readTime: "6 min read", }, ]; const featuredPost = { id: 0, title: "Building a Full-Stack App with Next.js and Postgres", excerpt: "A comprehensive guide to building production-ready applications using Next.js, Server Actions, and PostgreSQL. We'll cover everything from project setup to deployment.", date: "January 27, 2026", category: "Full Stack", readTime: "12 min read", }; const hasMorePosts = false; export default function Home() { return (
{/* Header */}
New Blog!
{/* Hero / Featured Post */}

{featuredPost.title}

{featuredPost.excerpt}

{featuredPost.date} · {featuredPost.readTime} · {featuredPost.category}
{/* Recent Posts */}

Recent Posts

{posts.map((post) => (
{post.category}

{post.title}

{post.excerpt}

{post.date} · {post.readTime}
))}
{/* Load More */}

); }

content.thinking: Done. I added a `hasMorePosts` variable set to `false` and wrapped the "Load more posts" button in a conditional render. The button will only show when `hasMorePosts` is true.

content.text: Done. Added a `hasMorePosts` flag at line 56 and wrapped the "Load more posts" button in a conditional render at lines 123-129. The button will only display when `hasMorePosts` is `true`.
